addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord the L. Burghley, Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.

page.lettertext:
fol.70r
May it please yo
r
good L. my last unto yo
w
, the
21 of this moneth, was an answear to her
Ma
ties
letters of
e 10 and to yo
r
L. of
e 7 and 10
of
e same. Wherein, as then, I could not write of
any certain resolution, that
e states had taken.
But after many meetinges, they have nowe deter-
mined, to
e same effect, as they by their letters
will signifie themselves, That
e greatest part
of their forces shalbe presently dispatched for
Brabant
:
w
t
special charge to annoy
e Ene-
mie in those quarters, by all meanes possible, and
to enter also into
Hennault
,
as farre as they
are able. Whereby they are in hope, that the
Duke of Parma
therupon, will ether retire, or
send some part of his strength, to relieve those
contreis. Moreover they have receaved
freshe letters from their Agent in
France
, by whome
they are solicited, in
e name of
e King, to imploy
their forces, above all other places, into
Flanders
.
For whiche cause, and because her Ma
tie
hath made
e self same motion, they have concluded to in-
treat her Hig
nes
by their letters, to send to
Ostend
or to some other part of Flanders, some conveni-
ent company of men, w
t
whome they have re-
solved, upon certificat given of
e nomber, time
and place, to joine so many more of their owne
troupes, as together w
t
her Ma
ties
may be able to per-
fourme some singular exploit. It is
further heere agreed, that
e specialties of their
late negotiation, w
t
e Germane Ambassado
rs
, shall be
sent to
M
r
Ortell
, to be related to her Hig
nes
fol.70v
The places whiche they have promised to restoare,
are Budricke, and Luttekehove, and some other
litle fortes, that belong to
Cleve
. Also now
ei
will give over Graeff, w
ch
was wonne by
S
r
Francis Vere
,
e 16 of this moneth: and, since
at
time,
e Beeke, a castel of good strength, w
ch
we are newly advertised S
r
Francis hath taken.
Because
e maintenance of garrisons in those
places would prove very chargeable to
e states,
and litle benefit come of it, they have thought
it better, to deliver them over to
e
Duke of Cleve
,
as a neutral person, then to hold them any
longer for themselves. Nevertheles, as I have
signified heere in Councel, they have made
this accord, against
e 21 Article of their
Contract w
t
her Ma
tie
, wherein it is provided,
that they shall not only not treat w
t
e Enemie,
but w
t
no other Prince or Potentat stranger,
w
t
out
e special privitie and approbation of
her Ma
tie
. Whiche of all other maters they
might worst seeme to doe in
e restitution of
those fortes, whiche were conquered so lately, w
t
e losse of
e lives of her Ma
ties
subjectes. Happely
my speeches hereof, have moved them to acquaint
her Hig
nes
w
t
their maner of proceeding: w
ch
they might have done before, during
e aboade
of
e Ambassado
rs
heere, whiche was five weekes
at
e lest. At
e writing
herof,
Rainold Peterson
of
Horne
is come unto
me, of whome I have enquired, as yo
r
L. willed,
fol.71r
But he knoweth nothing more, then I have certi-
fied before. For of those particular markes, w
ch
yo
r
L. would knowe, for
e better discovery
of
e partie, because he never sawe him in per-
son, but hath all his informations from his cosen
of
Embden
, he can not answear me to any thing.
Howbeit, if his cosen be returned out of
Spaine
,
as he supposeth he is, or wilbe very shortly, he
hath promised to procure him to come hither, or
to certifie by writing, w
at
soever he knoweth.
Also he himself doth goe for Spaine, w
t
in this moneth,
and profereth to enquire not only of this mater,
but of any thing els,
a t I shall require him, and
a man of profession may conveniently
learne.
M
r
Gilpin
doth calle to
minde, that
M
r
Wilkes
being heere, told him of
one, as farre as he can remember, an Arra-
gonese, that should come out of Spaine or
Portu-
gal
to
Don Antonio
, and hath acquainted her
Ma
tie
w
t
some special meanes, to troble
K. Philip
in his owne dominions. He can not say distin-
ctly, what was told him, but some suche mater
was told him: w
ch
I would not omitte to impart
w
t
yo
r
L. because of some likelihood, that
he might prove to be
e same partie. And
thus I take my humble leave.
At
e
Hage
.
Sep
t
22 1590.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden
Tho. Bodley
